item.title: Coalition crackdown on class action suits
item.description: Litigation funders who bankroll class action lawsuits are coming under the microscope amid concerns they claw back too much of the final settlements from successful cases.

item.title: China ‘to test all Wuhan’ amid virus fears
item.description: Authorities in the Chinese city where the coronavirus pandemic first broke out are planning to test all 11 million residents in the next 10 days, local media have reported.

item.title: Hospital at centre of Tas outbreak reopens
item.description: The hospital at the centre of a deadly coronavirus outbreak in northwest Tasmania will fully reopen a month after it was forced to close.

item.title: NSW pubs and clubs to open for dining
item.description: Patrons will soon be able to return to their favourite pubs and clubs for food service although bars and gaming facilities will remain closed across NSW.

item.title: UK economy shrank by record 5.8% in March
item.description: Britain's economy shrank by a record 5.8 per cent in March from February as the coronavirus crisis escalated and the government ordered a shutdown of much of the country to stop the spread of the virus, official data shows.

item.title: GM crops now allowed in SA as ban goes
item.description: New laws to allow genetically-modified crops to be grown on the South Australian mainland have passed state parliament.

item.title: S.Korea relaxes rules despite virus spike
item.description: South Korea health authorities have no immediate plans to reinstate strict social distancing rules despite a fresh coronavirus outbreak in Seoul.

item.title: WorkSafe investigates Cedar Meats cluster
item.description: WorkSafe has launched an investigation into a COVID-19 outbreak at a meat processing facility in Melbourne's west, which is linked to 88 infections.

item.title: Fear of second virus wave stalks markets
item.description: Global stocks and oil prices have fallen as fears about a second wave of coronavirus infections grip financial markets.

item.title: NSW upper house passes coronavirus bills
item.description: Frontline workers who keep NSW moving during the coronavirus pandemic will be better protected under workers' compensation laws should they catch COVID-19 following the passage of emergency legislation.
